awd_titl_txt: Dynamical and Statistical Methods Applied to Hamiltonian Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is devoted to research on dynamical systems that represent mathematical models of complex physical systems evolving over time. Dynamical systems of interest include mechanical systems (e.g., motion of satellites under the influence of gravity, solar pressure, electromagnetic forces, etc.), astrophysics system (e.g., expansion of the early universe, motion near a Black Hole, and evolution of exoplanetary systems), and high energy physics (e.g., particle accelerators, and plasma confinement devices). The goal of this research is to analyze and predict patterns of complex behavior emerging from the dynamics, and to obtain statistical information on the long-term evolution of the underlying systems. The obtained results are expected to contribute towards advancing scientific discovery and promoting innovative technologies, for example to design more efficient satellite orbits, to optimize performance of particle accelerators, and to understand more about the formation and evolution of the universe and of our solar system. Additionally, this project integrates research with education, and contributes towards preparing a diverse, highly qualified mathematics workforce.

At the fundamental level, the mathematical models to be investigated by this project can be framed in the formalism of Hamiltonian dynamics. A quintessential question is to understand the long-term behavior of orbits in Hamiltonian systems. This question is investigated in the context of nearly-integrable Hamiltonian systems (the Arnold diffusion problem), in the context of the N-body problem, and in the context of randomly perturbed Hamiltonian systems. The main objective of the research is to obtain qualitative and quantitative information on typical orbits in such systems. The information of interest concerns the distance traveled, speed and stability of orbits, the measure/Hausdorff dimension of the set of initial conditions for orbits that visit a prescribed sequence of targets, and the statistical distribution of orbits evolving from an initial data set.  For this purpose, the investigator and his colleagues develop innovative methodologies that combine geometric, topological, and statistical methods, which can be applied to concrete examples, and can be implemented in high-precision numerical computations and computer assisted proofs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has been focused on fundamental questions in dynamical systems ranging from celestial mechanics (e.g., on the motion of planets, comets, or spacecraft under the influence of gravity) to astrophysics (e.g., on the effects of galactic force due to dark and baryonic matter). Several mathematical models that can be framed under the formalism of Hamiltonian dynamics have been investigated. The main goal of this project has been to obtain qualitative and quantitative information on the long-term behavior of orbits in Hamiltonian systems.

In terms of intellectual merit, the project made significant advancement in several directions.

A first direction is on the Arnold diffusion problem, concerning the effect on small perturbations on integrable Hamiltonian systems. A geometric mechanism for the existence of diffusing orbits (i.e., orbits that travel significant distances in the phase space) has been devised in the a priori stable case, when the unperturbed Hamiltonian can be described in terms of action-angle variables only.  In a different model, of a so called  a priori chaotic system, detailed quantitative information has been obtained. The Arnold diffusion mechanism was also applied to systems with small dissipation, which appear in many applications, including energy harvesting devices. There are also applications to celestial mechanics, such as on the motion of an asteroid relative to the Neptune-Triton system, or on the motion of a spacecraft relative to the Sun-Earth system. Another significant application concerns the dynamics of asteroids in the main belt (located between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter); the results of this project give an explanation for the distributions of asteroids (the so called Kirkwood gaps).

A second direction of the research is on celestial mechanics and space mission design. A mechanism on how to change the inclination relative to the ecliptic of a satellite, with low fuel, has been found.  Another problem concerns orbits around irregularly shaped asteroids. The results of the project show all possible evolutions for orbits that pass very close to collision. Another result concerns the N-body problem in curved spaces, which are fundamental in Einstein's general relativity; the research shows that all non-degenerate relative equilibria solutions can be continued from flat spaces to curved spaces. An important tool in the design of fuel-efficient space mission design is the so called weak stability boundary, which has been already implemented in several missions by the space agencies NASA, ESA, JAXA. This project further explored weak stability boundaries, and discovered some relations between them and Mandelbrot sets in complex dynamics.     

A third direction of the research was devoted to astrophysics. The project led to significant results on the distribution of dark matter near our solar system and found a way to directly measure it. The results on dark matter are important for NASA for the design of space missions far from the Sun, since they imply that the galactic force due to dark and baryonic matter of the Galaxy needs to be considered as a perturbative factor.

In terms of broader impacts, the project made significant contributions to education and training of students. Four doctoral students (among which three are members of underrepresented groups) have been supported by the award and were engaged in research pertaining to this project.  A research experiences for undergraduates (REU) program has been conducted during summer 2021, with a significant participation of students - including high-schoolers - from the US and abroad. The educational activities also included organizing international conferences, seminars, research programs, as well as supervising projects by master's and undergraduate students.  The research on dark matter made a significant impact on space science research. NASA headquarters in Washington had a major press release on the results, which were further publicized by the scientific media across the world.
